author: Alternative_Joke6768
body: I would also take a look at atlassian, fortinet, splunk and akamai. There are also cyber ETFs but I would stay away from those personally.

author: dustensalinas
body:
I'm am a CTO.  This.. absolutely this!

'Serverless', edge computing is finally catching on.  Old school IT doesnt understand it but those that do, understand that you can reach world scale, amazing performance and on a dime in terms of operational costs.  For those that are unfamiliar, almost all of these companies provide a model where you can develop a product, get it out there with minimal capital costs and have almost all of it be operational costs that scale with the success of the product.  Infrastructure as a service is an intermediate step and is what AWS made its initial $ on.  Yet there are still folks with servers in centers or under their desk operated by individuals.  There are decision breakpoints the savvy execs look at of when to do which but there is no question in my mind the companies mentioned will win or be bought on the rise.

Fastly too has a great offering, unfortunately lost a few clients causing their earnings of late.

Cloudflare is my favorite as I see what they are doing to not just do a better job cheaper but also advance everything. This appeals to me in many ways, they were undervalued, have a solid structure in place and are pushing everything forward.  Hey if they get popular here, I wouldnt mind either ;)

Akamai has sat on its cash cow for so long, they have the cash and ability to do big things but unless its an enterprise deal or third party through a cloud provider they rarely are part of the conversation.

author: greytoc
body:
Company stocks can fall and it can take years and sometimes decades to recover. 

There were quite a few well known high-flying tech stocks in the 90's and early 2000's that never recovered or are only now recovering.  The ones that always pop into my mind include Cisco, Intel, GE, Akamai, VeriSign, Checkpoint. Citrix. I'm sure there are more examples including companies that eventually failed or were delisted. 

And please don't ask me why they pop into my mind.

author: MattEdmondsWolf
body: I am wondering what people here think of Limelight Networks (LLNW).  Stock is currently trading at around $2.50 per share so it is definitely a penny stock.  I'd be looking to buy a small position (no more than 1% of my portfolio). I see growth potential, however, I also think there is at least an equal chance that a competitor like Akamai will eat their lunch.  Please note that I generally think penny stocks should be avoided due to high failure rates among the underlying businesses and they are typically more difficult to evaluate than their more established peers..  What do you think?

author: MattEdmondsWolf
body: If I may ask - why do you think Limelight has fallen behind their competitors such that they are not seriously considered when picking an CDN service for your clients?  I am asking this question as I am still trying to get enough of a grasp of the company and whether it really has the growth potential I think it has or if I am better off skipping them and investing in in the likes of Akamai, Fastly, or CloudFlare.

author: greytoc
body:
I have no comment about the actual stock since I've not looked at their fundamentals. 

Pure anecdotal comment from my perspective - I wanted to mention that Limelight as a CDN service has really fallen behind their larger competitors like Fastly, Cloudflare, and Akamai. Most times - I forget that Limelight even still exist. They generally don't make it on the short list when CDN services are being evaluated - at least not with my clients that use CDN services.  

If I wanted to invest in a CDN player - they are probably not one that I would choose.

author: aurelius94
body:
Provides content distribution network functionality for its customers.

Think of it like this: The server you're requesting data from is in New York but you're in Berlin. Instead of the content going across the world every time, the resource you're requesting is instead cached at a continental or even national level by Fastly, meaning instead of going to America, your request discretely goes to Amsterdam instead. Response time is vastly superior and your browsing experience much snappier as a result.

Same as NET or Akamai.

author: motterpaul
body:
Reopening stocks (CZR and LVS) are showing decent ERs  - but keep in mind most of that is pre-Delta reclose.

AKAM tanking - rare miss

author: Trex_in_F16
body: As someone who works closely in that sector, Its a highly capital intensive business and akamai owns most of the internet cdns

author: Lorddon1234
body: Is Fastly really a better company than Akamai?

author: Summebride
body: Content distribution networks for Internet sites.  They copy the main web site, then have super fast versions of it around the outer reaches of the Internet so many people can all access it quickly without bogging down the source site.  They can provide enough capacity for the smallest website to be accessible to the whole world. They also make the sites secure.  Akamai and Cloudflare do similar things.  Fastly is probably the most technically advanced, and they have the least number of customers, but the customers they do have are giant, like Amazon and Microsoft.
